channel.title: Sum of Geometric Finite Series
channel.description:
I don't exactly need help, I just need some advice. My class just started to sum finite geometric series, (sigma etc.) and I was starting to notice a pattern, besides the one that the book gave. The normal formula given, is: [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = (t[sub]1[/sub](1 - r[sup]n[/sup])) / (1 - r)[/b] ------------------------------------------- S[sub]n[/sub] being the sum of the series, n being the number of terms, r being the common ratio, and t[sub]1[/sub] being the first term in the sequence.
I noticed that if you took the common ratio to the power of n (r[sup]n[/sup]), and r being 2 (2[sup]n[/sup])you were only a subtraction away from the sum of the series. To show my point: 1+2+4+8+16; r=2; t[sub]1[/sub]=1;n=5; Using the normal formula (or your head), you get 31. But, r[sup]n[/sup] (2[sup]5[/sup]) = 32, and t[sub]1[/sub]=1.
I thought it was just coincidence. But I kept trying and trying, and I realized that this formula also works, as long as the ratio is 2: [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = (r[sup]n[/sup])(t[sub]1[/sub]) - t[sub]1[/sub][/b] I emailed my math teacher, and she said it was good, but that it didn't have much use if it only worked with r = 2. But I realized that[b] S[sub]n[/sub] = (r[sup]n[/sup])(t[sub]1[/sub]) - t[sub]1[/sub][/b] is the same as [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = ((r[sup]n[/sup])(t[sub]1[/sub]) - t[sub]1[/sub]) / 1[/b] and r - 1 = 1. I then changed my formula to this: [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = ((r[sup]n[/sup])(t[sub]1[/sub]) - t[sub]1[/sub]) / (r-1)[/b]
My question is, which formula would you use: [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = (t[sub]1[/sub](1 - r[sup]n[/sup])) / (1 - r)[/b] or [b]S[sub]n[/sub] = ((r[sup]n[/sup])(t[sub]1[/sub]) - t[sub]1[/sub]) / (r-1)[/b]
Please explain why

w=fd
d = displacement, not distance, Davidi2, you imbecilic person you.

Why the hell did you even bring up the work formula.[/quote]
w=mad

item.title: Sum of Geometric Finite Series
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:26, topic:340098”][quote author=Cain_ link=topic=436475.msg3220316#msg3220316 date=1275124701]
That too. Though I have a feeling I may be misunderstanding him. I guess i’ll find out soon.
[/quote]
David’s saying that distributed equations are more efficient than ones that are factored. But if you’re given an equation and you need to solve for x, you can’t ‘save a step’, because that equation is either factored or not, etc.

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=436475.msg3220252#msg3220252 date=1275113556]

[quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=436475.msg3220022#msg3220022 date=1275095477]

Many Most college graduates are dumb as fuck, and your teacher proves that.

You clearly do not understand that when you have to solve a problem on a test, you are given the specific problem. You cannot ‘save a step’. lolololol
[/quote]Why don’t you understand… I am not talking about the ‘answer’ to the problem, it’s about how you get the answer. Of course you can save a step, that’s common sense. For example, think of a city block.

A---------------------B
| |
| |
| |
| |
| |
| |
C---------------------D

You want to get from A to B. You can get there by going from A to C to D to B, or you can go A to B. You SAVE A STEP, but you STILL GET THE SAME ANSWER.

The work done by the person is still the same, so the ‘efficiency’ (lolololol) is the same. lolol
[/quote]Really? I never knew that going 3 blocks took the same amount of work as going 1 block. Must be some new type of math your teachers taught you.

Wow, this is what I mean by incompetent. w=fd[/quote]
Obviously you misunderstood me, because I also gave another example:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:24, topic:340098”]Just like you could factor a quadratic rather than use the quadratic formula.[/quote]Which is not just a factored equation.

And are you saying that going 1 block is the same as going 3 blocks? Because that is utterly retarded.

EDIT: EOD:

[quote=“Moparisthebest”]I believe you are all confusing work, and perhaps displacement. You calculate work like this:

work = force * distance

Therefore, since going the long way around means longer distance, it means more work was done.

However, the end result (maybe the correct word is displacement, but it’s late and I haven’t taken physics for years) is the same either way.[/quote]

You SAVE A STEP, but you STILL GET THE SAME ANSWER.

Read full topic

The work done by the person is still the same, so the ‘efficiency’ (lolololol) is the same. lolol

item.description:

[quote=“Cain_, post:1, topic:341768”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=436475.msg3220022#msg3220022 date=1275095477]

Many Most college graduates are dumb as fuck, and your teacher proves that.

| |

| |

You want to get from A to B. You can get there by going from A to C to D to B, or you can go A to B. You SAVE A STEP, but you STILL GET THE SAME ANSWER.

The work done by the person is still the same, so the ‘efficiency’ (lolololol) is the same. lolol

Just a quick example - the remainder theorem is much faster (and maybe easier) than using long division to find if a given number is a factor. Is this not an example that goes against what you’re saying?[/quote]Just like you could factor a quadratic rather than use the quadratic formula.

item.title: Sum of Geometric Finite Series
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:18, topic:340098”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=436475.msg3217626#msg3217626 date=1274834148]

[quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=436475.msg3215668#msg3215668 date=1274649871]

What do you mean ‘it saves a step’? If you’re given a(a+2)=32, you’re given that. If you’re given a^2+2a-32=0, you’re given that. What the hell do you mean by ‘saves a step’…? And how can an equation be inefficient? Use some logic, seriously.

Edit: And pls explain why you would use the quadratic formula.
[/quote]The step you don’t need to do is multiplying everything out. It’s called distribution.

And I never said it was inefficient? I just asked which was more efficient than another.

Why the fuck are you so concentrated on that example? I could not care less about the quadratic formula, and it was completely off-topic to ask about it.

WHEN YOU’RE GIVEN A PROBLEM BY YOUR TEACHER, YOU’RE GIVEN THE SPECIFIC PROBLEM. YOU CAN’T ‘SAVE A STEP’. God… And… SINCE WHEN HAVE EQUATIONS HELD DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES? LOL.
[/quote]As I said before, it was a discussion question for (in general) if factored or distributed equations are more efficient when it comes to solving them. The following day, the teacher said that she thought that distributed equations are more efficient, but less pretty and easy to read.

And why can’t you save a step? And by efficiency I mean the time taken to solve. If you mean something else, please explain. Because obviously two equations with the same outcome can take more or less time to solve than the other.

No wonder you’re so incompetent; it’s your teacher’s fault.[/quote]Are you trying to say you are smarter than a College Graduate? Because I extremely doubt they would hire someone that didn’t know what they were talking about. I also noticed you are not answering my questions:

And why can't you save a step? And by efficiency I mean the time taken to solve. If you mean something else, please explain. Because obviously two equations with the same outcome can take more or less time to solve than the other.

Read full topic

item.title: Sum of Geometric Finite Series

item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:17, topic:340098”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=436475.msg3215668#msg3215668 date=1274649871]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=436475.msg3213688#msg3213688 date=1274507185]

What do you mean ‘it saves a step’? If you’re given a(a+2)=32, you’re given that. If you’re given a^2+2a-32=0, you’re given that. What the hell do you mean by ‘saves a step’…? And how can an equation be inefficient? Use some logic, seriously.

Edit: And pls explain why you would use the quadratic formula.
[/quote]The step you don’t need to do is multiplying everything out. It’s called distribution.

And I never said it was inefficient? I just asked which was more efficient than another.

Why the fuck are you so concentrated on that example? I could not care less about the quadratic formula, and it was completely off-topic to ask about it.

WHEN YOU’RE GIVEN A PROBLEM BY YOUR TEACHER, YOU’RE GIVEN THE SPECIFIC PROBLEM. YOU CAN’T ‘SAVE A STEP’. God… And… SINCE WHEN HAVE EQUATIONS HELD DIFFERENT EFFICIENCIES? LOL.
[/quote]As I said before, it was a discussion question for (in general) if factored or distributed equations are more efficient when it comes to solving them. The following day, the teacher said that she thought that distributed equations are more efficient, but less pretty and easy to read.

And why can’t you save a step? And by efficiency I mean the time taken to solve. If you mean something else, please explain. Because obviously two equations with the same outcome can take more or less time to solve than the other.[/quote]
No wonder you’re so incompetent; it’s your teacher’s fault.

Read full topic

item.title: Sum of Geometric Finite Series
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:12, topic:340098”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=436475.msg3211917#msg3211917 date=1274319924]

Of course adding random variables to an equation is inefficient.
[/quote]yup.

But factoring can also change how efficient an equation is.
For example,

a(a + 2) = 32 a^2 + 2a = 32 a^2 + 2a - 32 = 0 a = (-2 +(or minus) sqr(4+4(1)(-32))) / 2 etc...
If you just write it in un-factored form, (a^2 + 2a = 32) you save a step.

Not really. And why would you even use the quadratic formula?[/quote]Please explain how that does not save a step??? And it was just an example… not actually trying to solve anything.

Read full topic
